question: 間もなく
sourceMnemonic:
The <ja>もなく</ja> part is like saying "there isn't even." So, when "there isn't even <kanji>an interval of time</kanji>," things will happen <vocabulary>soon</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>before long</vocabulary>.

You'll probably hear this the most in train announcements letting you know your train will <vocabulary>shortly</vocabulary> be arriving in Tokyo or wherever.
sourceReadingMnemonic:
The reading for this one is weird, though. It's a second kun'yomi reading (there is also <ja>あいだ</ja>), read as <ja>ま</ja>. So what is happening <vocabulary>soon</vocabulary>? Your <reading>Ma</reading> is going to be here <vocabulary>before long</vocabulary>. You better hurry and prepare, because your room looks terrible... 

"<ja>間もなく</ja>, your mom is about to show up!"
